Lt. JG. Drevas Kniel 21-Jan-21 05:03 PM
"That is good to hear. Alright." He looked solemnly at the group once around the table. "We have our work cut out for us - as has been made painfully evident. Thank you all for your bravery so far. Please continue to do the good work that you have done throughout. Until the next time we meet like this... dismissed."
Lt. Cmdr. Rekat Parlac 21-Jan-21 05:05 PM
Parlac nodded to his colleagues and headed for the door. He hated to look like he was in a rush to leave, but the work that was mounting for the Noi mission was taking top priority in his headspace and he wanted to check in with Oskar for an update.
Lt. JG. Maggie Verne 21-Jan-21 05:07 PM
Maggie nodded as she stood up with a sigh, running a hand though her sliver hair before slipping out and heading into the hallway.
Commander T'Svai 21-Jan-21 05:08 PM
T'Svai stood, nodded stiffly at Commander Dunamis, and left.
Lt. Cmdr. Amanda Higgins 21-Jan-21 05:08 PM
Amanda stood and gave her own nod before leaving.
Commander Blanche Carlisle 21-Jan-21 05:10 PM
Carlisle had become uncomfortably aware of the solemn state of her own expression. As such, she tried a polite smile before nodding as everyone else had, standing from her seat. "Thank you, Commander." With that, the woman collected her PADD from the table's surface and slipped out of the conference room.
Lt. JG. Drevas Kniel 21-Jan-21 05:12 PM
For a few minutes he sat in silent contemplation, expression grim - before shaking his head and walking out of the conference room. There was one among his senior staff he needed to speak to.
Lieutenant Sara Bjørge 21-Jan-21 05:15 PM
Sara had left as well after frantically typing down notes about the conference. Today was going to be very busy indeed.
Captain Syrezeaju 28-Jan-21 06:52 PM
The work didn't seem to have stopped for Syrezeaju. From medical she had returned straight here - opting for the conference room in her typical fashion, having had decidedly enough of the ready room that she so despised. The only good thing about it was the confiscated volleyball. Having turned the desk's console interface into her own personal workspace, she was currently reading over the latest filed reports. Nails tapped off the surface of the desk as she waited for the arrival of Dunamis. Wasn't he just up on the bridge? Weren't those long kelpien legs of him suited for going places quickly..? Maybe she was just getting more impatient by the day.
Lt. JG. Drevas Kniel 28-Jan-21 06:56 PM
He walked through the doors about two seconds later and joined her at the table - though he didn't sit just yet. He knew that she didn't quite like using her ready room, though he did think that here specifically was a rather sensible alternative. Spacious, quiet... it helped her think, maybe. "Captain. Reporting as ordered." (edited)
Captain Syrezeaju 28-Jan-21 06:59 PM
"Commander," she stated, offering a single glance up to him upon his initial statement - seemingly having ignored the sound of doors sliding open or the sound of footsteps upon the floor. "Please -- take a seat. I read over those two reports you've written. Command knows about the former, at least. Hopefully they'll get back to us relatively soon, but I know the lot of them must be ran off their feet right now."
Lt. JG. Drevas Kniel 28-Jan-21 07:05 PM
"They surely must be, especially in times such as these. The impending second Iconian War already strikes fear into the minds of our crew, as you know." He remaked as he sat down beside her. Scared shitless. Plummeting morale. Many had not signed up to go into combat, he knew. They'd wanted to see the universe. To expand their horizons beyond the confines of thier homes. No one had expected for those dreams to be crushed. (edited)
Captain Syrezeaju 28-Jan-21 07:09 PM
"Yes, Commander, I do know." Her tone was decidedly cold and rather unamused. "You stated it in your report - you are aware that everything submitted is visible to Command, correct? You might want to edit your word choice a little, next time." After locking the console she regarded the Kelpien who had taken the seat closest to her - an action she had noted with distaste, considering her appreciation of personal space. Red eyes seemed to analyse him. "That aside... When that away mission was first coming together - the one to apprehend Elija Noi - either Security or Intelligence told you about it, right? You were made aware of their plans - possibly had a brief meeting, possibly weighed in on the matter..?"
Lt. JG. Drevas Kniel 28-Jan-21 07:11 PM
"Yes. I was. Both told us about it in fact." Oh, right. He hadn't told her about it. The one person who should have weighed in on the mission in the first place. Yes, just wonderful indeed.
Captain Syrezeaju 28-Jan-21 07:18 PM
"Uh-huh. So you were aware of their plans to develop some sort of technology, aware of their plans to use the Aquarius, just... Aware? Generally aware?" The tone stayed cold - monotone, unnerving.
Lt. JG. Drevas Kniel 28-Jan-21 07:24 PM
"I spoke with the away team before they left - and with commander Parlac about the mission itself. I knew that they were to take the Chimera out on the mission. They were planning to develop technology so as to locate agent Noi through his telepathy enhancement chip." The tone worried him - though he did not let it show.
Captain Syrezeaju 28-Jan-21 07:31 PM
There was silence, only broken by the sound of her nails tapping off the console's surface again as she had been doing before. After what seemed to be painstakingly long she sat back, folding her arms across her chest. "So you effectively green-lit their plans and authorised the team to head out after one of the Federation's most notorious killers? And by 'the team' I mean my crew. ...Do you remember what I told you when I first came aboard, Dunamis? Because despite the brain damage, I do. Somethin' tells me you've forgotten."
Lt. JG. Drevas Kniel 28-Jan-21 07:40 PM
He too sat in silence for a while, sifting through his memories - before begrudgingly nodding. "Indeed I have. I did so begrudgingly - believing that the risk agent Noi posed is - was - far too great to simply ignore."
Captain Syrezeaju 28-Jan-21 07:46 PM
"Too great to ignore that you didn't think to consult me, huh? I told you that we needed to be a team. That Command wasn't mutually exclusive, that in order to get the best results we would have to work together. It's... Somethin' that you've neglected, I've noticed. And I've noticed because others have noticed as well. Lieutenant Commander Parlac thought I knew of the details of their away mission when I didn't even know it existed. Lieutenant Bjørge thought I was aware of what was discussed at that department head meeting. It's come to my attention that the majority of what I know is from reports - ones not written by you, might I add. In fact..." There was another pause. It was difficult to tell if she was contemplative, analytical, or just downright angry. "Did I hear from you once over the course of what, the month and a half that I was out..?"
Lt. JG. Drevas Kniel 28-Jan-21 07:47 PM
"No." Even he had to admit that.
Captain Syrezeaju 28-Jan-21 07:51 PM
"So-" She started, shuffling back a little in her chair. Her head tilted to the side ever so slightly as she regarded him with those snake-like eyes. "-Do you wanna explain why?"
Lt. JG. Drevas Kniel 28-Jan-21 08:04 PM
Again he was silent. He had no good reason for the captain. He really didn't. He'd failed in his duty to be the crew's liaison to her. That meant keeping her informed of happenings, of any kind. Instead he'd tried to shoulder everything on his own. Where did that leave him, then? "...I wanted you to rest and recover without worrying. But I realize that I should have at least kept you informed."
7
Captain Syrezeaju 28-Jan-21 08:13 PM
"The least you could have done, yes. Here was me thinking that you had done a fine job of keeping the ship afloat, Commander, only to find that all you've done is neglect to inform me of anything, fail to report to Command, and run what - one department head meeting..? Sure, it stayed afloat - because everyone else did their jobs. Communication is the basis of a functional crew. I'd like to think you would understand that, considering you were demoted for lack of it before."
Lt. JG. Drevas Kniel 28-Jan-21 08:15 PM
Yes, he had. There was no denying that. "I do. And I failed to keep that in mind. I'm sorry, Captain."
Captain Syrezeaju 28-Jan-21 08:28 PM
"I'm glad you can at least apologise, Commander," she ground out - that gravelly, electronic grumble cold enough that it sounded akin to crunching ice. "Look at me. We don't have to be friends. We don't have to like each other in any way, shape, or form. But if there's one thing we have to do, that's work together in a professional environment. We have an ship of 1285 officers and crewmen alike who damned well depend on us. Start acting like you realise that fact."
Lt. JG. Drevas Kniel 28-Jan-21 08:30 PM
"I will, captain." Words are one thing. Actions are another. He met her gaze firmly, gold to red. If he was sincere about his intentions he could damn well start by looking her in the blinking eyes.
Captain Syrezeaju 28-Jan-21 08:44 PM
"Good," came the firm statement in response. "Make sure you remember that, this time. ...Dismissed."
Lt. JG. Drevas Kniel 28-Jan-21 08:46 PM
Wordlessly, he stood and left the conference room.. (edited)
Captain Syrezeaju 30-Jan-21 10:18 PM
“Fuck,” Syrezeaju stated, staring at the message that had flickered up onto the PADD sat before her. ”Fuck,” she stated again, this time more forceful – just in case the world hadn’t heard her. ”Fuck!” She shouted this time, snatching up the PADD from the desk and proceeding to lob it across the room as hard as she physically could. It bounced off the wall and came clattering back against the conference room’s table, landing comically close to where she had originally picked it up from. The action earned a deep growl of frustration from her as she forcefully pushed back her chair to stand, leaving it almost toppling over in the process. It was around the table that she now prowled, fingernails digging into her hair as she tugged at it in frustration. The lack of sleep had seemed to hit her like a ton of bricks, mood swings becoming dangerously violent. It was no wonder that she had hidden away here where the crew did not have to face her wrath. The Rigellian muttered as she prowled, words clipped in anger. “What am I supposed to do with this, huh? What am I supposed to do with this? Do Command think- Do Command think this is fucking funny? Have they forgotten this is a war? This is a bloody war and they’ve just gone and taken away the fucking CTO and the XO?! An’ don’t get me wrong, they both piss me off, but if there’s one thing Dunamis it’s being good with this crew. What am I meant to do now, huh? Just wait until they send me someone new? Watch them fail to integrate the same as me? Well? Well?!” Her questions had been thrown at what appeared to be mid-air. The image that she had been seeing – one of the Rigellian spirits, she had been certain – dissipated into nothingness. Wide, red eyes stared after it for a moment, blinking – and then it only earned a further long, drawn-out snarl that she very much would have like to have turned into a full scream. At least she had a little restraint.
The hallucinations had been plaguing her for a few hours. It was unsurprising that they had been begun; not even the Rigellian could go this long without sleep before her brain started conjuring what wasn’t there. The desk tilted to the side from time to time, invisible blood poured from her neck, people flickered into existence - and all the while she sat there firmly believing that it was real until it vanished. It was like a bad acid trip, entirely disconcerting. Of course the spirit figure hadn’t been real. She had always been bad at the spirit walk and had she attempted it recently? No – although it might have been useful, given her present state. The anger was overwhelming and even if they could not fix everything then they might as well have been able to calm her down. Lights started flickering in the right side of her vision. It was with a grimace that she turned away only to find the orbs still in existence to the other side of the room. Her palm was swiftly pressed to her right eye in response but not even obscuring her vision could cut out the strange lights. Ringing seemed to start in her ears – distant but loud enough to mute out everything else, and it was getting closer. Shit, she thought to herself. Shit. How long had it been since she had taken any of the medication on that stupidly long list? Day one had been forgotten, day two had been purposefully ignored, day three and four and five and six and… The rest had been ignored as well, the clarity feeling like she could get away with it. Perhaps it hadn’t been clarity at all, but delusion instead. The medication made her hands tremble, her head ache, her stomach churn – it was only understandable that she had stopped taking them. Right? Cursing the mangled layout of her brain, Syrezeaju swiftly exited the conference room – only pausing to snatch the PADD up as she left.
Ensign Alyx Morgan 09-Feb-21 03:16 PM
They entered and looked around briefly to see if anyone was currently in here, before going straight over to the replicator. They pulled a sheet of two decals out of their satchel, before peeling off the first and applying it to one side of the replicator while using a small paddle to remove any air bubbles. After applying the first they repeated the process for the second. After completing the installation they stepped back to make sure the decals were level, before heading back out.
Commander T'Svai 16-Feb-21 12:46 AM
As she sat down at the head of the conference room table and started going through her notes, she found herself momentarily overwhelmed by a wave of emotion that had her blinking back tears. When she'd planned on becoming a science officer (which of course had spontaneously changed into operations officer, which had equally spontaneously turned into command* officer) she had not anticipated seeing, of all things, children being exposed to the horrors of war. It was not easy to hear such things recounted, nor see a Vulcan child brought to tears, a sight worsened by their need to apologize after the fact. She supposed it was not necessarily illogical to be strongly moved in the face of cruelty. Anyway. Once she'd composed herself, a process which took approximately five seconds, she resumed going over her notes, wondering when the others would arrive.
Lt. JG. Zulola Jex 16-Feb-21 12:53 AM
Lola stepped into the conference room, Gronk the birded dragon upon her shoulder. Lola's hair was up neatly in a pony tail, and her uniform was only slightly bloody. She hadn't had the time to change. "Lieutenant Jex reporting, sir!"
Commander T'Svai 16-Feb-21 12:56 AM
T'Svai looked up and was that blood? "Indeed." She said, raising an eyebrow. "Is that your blood, Lieutenant?" She asked bluntly.
Lt. JG. Zulola Jex 16-Feb-21 12:59 AM
Lola shook her head. "No, sir. I can explain in my report, though?"
Commander T'Svai 16-Feb-21 01:00 AM
T'Svai nodded, then nodded at Gronk and subsequently realized she was greeting a lizard. By Surak, she needed to meditate. "That is the logical choice. Please take a seat, Lieutenant, and tell me what happened."
7
7
Lt. JG. Zulola Jex 16-Feb-21 01:15 AM
Lola took a seat as she was asked. "So, the beginning, I believe is the... logical place to start, so we stepped into the NGL Cetus and were almost immediately pelted with by flour and water. We made our way down the halls till we got to the bridge. Lt. Howard went to do something at the door, I can't remember what, and tripped. She hit the door, which was apparently electrically charged. The electricity shorted out her suit and she had to be sent back to the Chimera, which was good for us in the end. After that, we headed to the maintenence shaft and started climbing down, since we read that the life signs were on deck 2. As we made our way down, we were pelted with volleyballs by the kids. They are real little monsters when they want to be. Anyways, we made contact with one of them. He clearly didn't trust us and ran off. Presumably to get jello, cause that's what hit us next." Lola paused in her report for a brief moment to let the commander take notes and ask questions.
Commander T'Svai 16-Feb-21 01:17 AM
T'Svai received that report without any noticeable reaction, save for one corner of her mouth twitching up juuuuust a little as she ducked her head down in a completely non-evasive way to look at her PADD and take notes. Even hearing it a second time was, admittedly, amusing. "Ah, yes, the improvised defense system. Please continue."
Lt. JG. Zulola Jex 16-Feb-21 02:19 AM
Lola smiled a bit herself. It was pretty funny, now that she thought about it. It certainly was not funny when it happened, though. "Well, we finally got onto deck to and Lt. T'Khael took a hit from a frying pan. The kids were using some kind of swinging device, device to throw kitchen-ware at us. She wasn't hurt at all, though there was a little girl who fell out of the wall and into their glue traps. These kids put glue on everything, by the way. Anyways, the girl got stuck in the glue, we used phasers to get her out, and a little boy attacked us. We caught him, the girl escaped, and it took about 15 minutes of talking and Lieutenant T'Khael taking off her helmet to convince the kid to trust us. "After that, the kids, Roka I believe his name was, led us to the others. The little girl from before, Camille, took the Commander Itesh and Ensign Ota to the bridge while I gave all the children radiation inoculations. Lieutenant T'Khael stayed with me. The kids were so scared and hungry, they trusted me fairly easily. There were two kids that were more sick than the rest. After I explained to them what I was doing, I gave them their inoculations so they wouldn't suffer from further radiation poisoning, then I gave them food rations from my bag. "I tried taking their minds off of their situations by talking to them. I explained to them what a CO was, and we told them what our races were. They were so cute. We were about to discuss happy memories when we were told Lieutenant Howard was ready to beam us to sickbay. I told them they needed to hold hands or wrists so that no one got lost in the transfer, but really I was just making sure all 18 kids were accounted for." Lola went silent for a long moment. She really didn't like the next part, but it was all part of the report she needed to give. After all, nothing in the report she had given so far explained the blood on the uniform.
Commander T'Svai 16-Feb-21 02:22 AM
"I am unsurprised the little boy attacked, in the presence of phaser-fire." T'Svai remarked neutrally, adding the new information to the list. "It seems you have done an exceptional job bonding with the children. What happened after that?"
Lt. JG. Zulola Jex 16-Feb-21 02:45 AM
"The transport went well. The kids were excited about their new surroundings, so I just let them run loose. Then I got a comm from the commander saying that-" She paused, then cleared her throat. "Saying that they needed an emergency transport. The young girl that was in their charge fell down the maintenence shaft. I got her on a biobed as soon as possible to get a full scan on her. She was deferring from Cauda Equina syndrome and her L2 and L4 vertebrae were completely smashed." Lola took a moment to collect herself. "She was still awake. I had the commander tell me what happened as I administered an anesthetic and something to put her to sleep for awhile while I operated. I had her recite her name, age, and had her track my finger, just to keep her mind off of the situation she was in as she slipped under.. We had docked back to the Pheonix by then, so I called for medical assistance. Lieutenant Drake assisted me from there. I placed a neural blocker on her and operated on as soon as possible. It took about an hour and a half to finish the operation and to regrow her L2 and L4 vertebrae, but I managed. I couldn't have done it without Lieutenant Drake's help, though. "After that, I took the rest of my EV suit off and went through decon- I didn't have time beforehand, and Lieutenant Drake and I took Camille to sickbay proper. I already wrote my report and everything, as well, sir."
Commander T'Svai 16-Feb-21 02:48 AM
T'Svai made note of the rest of that as well in a series of neat, short bullet points. Then she put her PADD down, clasped her hands on the table, and leaned forward, expression still ostensibly neutral but with a gravity it had previously lacked. "Lieutenant Jex, you should know I was able to converse with one of the children earlier. They informed me of something you may find disturbing, if you were not aware already. Did your medical scans reveal anything other than exposure to polaric radiation?"
Lt. JG. Zulola Jex 16-Feb-21 02:53 AM
Lola's eyebrows furrowed as she thought back, then shook her head. "N-no sir. My scans only picked up concentrated points of radiation on the children. Everything was slightly confusing or blocked out by the radiation around us. There was something I missed??"
Commander T'Svai 16-Feb-21 02:56 AM
"Not precisely." T'Svai replied, brow furrowing slightly. "I was informed by one of the children, Lorian, that he and the other children had been injected with some as yet unidentified clear, odorless liquid substance by the invading force that disabled the Cetus." She explained. "I had hoped you might be able to identify its effects." She paused another long moment. "There was a certain...scientific bent to the entire process, as it was explained to me."
Lt. JG. Zulola Jex 16-Feb-21 03:21 AM
"Wait, I- I saw how much radiation was in that ship. With a dis how would he know that? The amount of radiation that they were exposed to should have knocked children their age out within moments." And now Lola was worried, and concerned, and a little confused. She sat there thinking for a moment. "No, really, it doesn't make sense. Radiation has a half-life, and from the time we received the distress signal to when we got there, the radiation was still incredibly high. The difference between the current level of radiation at that time versus the rate of decay over time should have been greater, meaning there was an inside force radiating a near constant source. The children must have been knocked out when the radiation first hit them, then woke up when their bodies either acclimated slightly to the radiation or when the radiation dissipated. Not completely, of course."
Commander T'Svai 16-Feb-21 03:25 AM
"You are correct, Lieutenant. According to Lorian, radiation-producing devices were beamed aboard, and remain there. I had hoped the intent of the injection was to prevent the children from succumbing to radiation poisoning, as indeed they are in remarkably good health, but can deduce no reason why the Iconians would seek to provide such a thing. They do not seem inclined towards gestures of goodwill, therefore there is at minimum a secondary function at work." She agreed, frowning very, very slightly. "But the fact remains - it could be anything. When you and others are treating these children, please continue to exercise the utmost caution." She picked up her PADD again. "If that is all, you and Gronk are dismissed."
3
3
Lt. JG. Zulola Jex 16-Feb-21 03:27 AM
Lola nodded and took her leave, but not before saying,. "Thank you, Commander. This has been.... enlightening."
Commander T'Svai 16-Feb-21 03:30 AM
Enlightening was a strange word to use, in T'Svai's opinion, but she supposed she knew what Lola meant. "Thank you, Lieutenant." She replied, promptly projecting the contents of her PADD up onto a screen to give the next person a framework, for the sake of avoiding redundancy.
- Arrived on Cetus - Flour and water - Howard electrocuted, returned to Chimera - Volleyballs, jello - Girl in glue trap - T'Khael removed helmet - Roka led party to chidlren - Children treated for radiation - Rapport established - Girl fell, rescued by Yllescas - Girl treated surgically by Jex and Drake - Decon and transfer
 (edited)
6
6
6
6
6
6
Commander T'Svai 16-Feb-21 09:07 PM
[D] Without hesitation, T'Svai initiated a site to site transport to sickbay.
Captain Syrezeaju 10-Mar-21 08:33 PM
The conference room was dark when she entered. Syrezeaju preferred it that way - the glaring light that Starfleet used aboard modern starships only served to give her a headache nowadays. She took a seat at the elongated oval table, leaning her head backwards against the back of the chair. An attempted murder aboard her ship... Damn it. She tapped her commbadge to contact the one she needed to speak with next.
Ensign Jaime Devereux 10-Mar-21 08:56 PM
[D] The door chimed.
Captain Syrezeaju 10-Mar-21 08:57 PM
"Door's unlocked," she called out, knowing that he must have chimed the door then stepped back automatically otherwise the doors would have opened. "Just come in."
Ensign Jaime Devereux 10-Mar-21 08:58 PM
Jaime stepped inside and saluted to the Rigellian. "Ensign Jaime Devereux reporting, sir!"
Captain Syrezeaju 10-Mar-21 09:09 PM
It was with a decidedly blank expression that she watched the Ensign - glad that they knew procedure, at least, but the weight of this situation could hardly weigh any time to her commending them for such. Instead she merely motioned to the chairs at one side of the table. "At ease, Ensign. Take a seat." (edited)
Ensign Jaime Devereux 10-Mar-21 09:13 PM
Jaime nodded and relaxed their stance somewhat, yet staying formal, before taking a seat at the table, opposite Syrezeaju. "You wanted to see me, sir?" (edited)
Captain Syrezeaju 10-Mar-21 09:16 PM
"Yes - and you already know why, Ensign, because we spoke about it on the comms." Folding her arms upon the table, the faint shimmer of red eyes only just visible through the dark seemed to watch him intently. "One officer is almost murdered by a chemical that should not have been activated within them. Another officer - low ranking and not from the Medical or Science divisions - miraculously procures an antidote despite the fact that they should not have been able to. Care to explain?"
Ensign Jaime Devereux 10-Mar-21 09:20 PM
"Sir... the cure was one of a large number of files I received recently, that previously belonged to my grandfather... I don't know much of what he did but he must have been involved with the dominion in some way... he may have been an intel agent for all I know... a lot of his job details were (and still are) classified."
Captain Syrezeaju 10-Mar-21 09:25 PM
"And amidst those files there conveniently was a cure - one that you noted and memorised?" She enquired, tilting her head a little. "Tell me, Ensign. If you did not know what your grandfather did for a living, then how did these files make their way into your possession? And if 'a lot of his job details were classified,' then how did they find their way to you - an Ensign, that is?"
Ensign Jaime Devereux 10-Mar-21 09:28 PM
"I did not have it memorised, sir... I had the formula available on a PADD along with most of the rest of his files. And in reference to the discrepancy in obtaining the files... ma mère thought it was possible they should have been erased when he retired from... wherever he worked."
Captain Syrezeaju 10-Mar-21 09:34 PM
Considering how the entire room was dark and the only glimmers of light allowed in were from the windows, it was rather difficult to make out her facial expression. What was evident, though, was how red eyes narrowed just a little. "That isn't an explanation. Those files - which were not erased, contrary to what your mother thought - still ended up with you. Should there have been the potential for them being classified, then they wouldn't have ended up in your hands." She sat back, then, and folded her arms across her chest. "The Federation and the Dominion has always had shaky ties at best; even during times when we're allied there has always still been tension. Any person who possibly had been involved with the Dominion would not be able to actively distribute files. If they were, as an attempt at... Let's say treason against the Dominion, for example, do you think that those files would be handed over to a miscellaneous Security Ensign instead of handed over to Command?"
Ensign Jaime Devereux 10-Mar-21 09:41 PM
"No sir... that's not what I believe... the files probably should have been given to Command... but they were with me... and if they weren't then we may have lost Ensign Nedras... in fact, we may still have lost him for all I know, unless the medical crew utilised the antidote," They said, timidly. In fact, they almost shrank back in their chair at the intensity of the Captain's gaze. They may have been trained to withstand certain interrogation techniques, but this Rigellian... she had the air of someone who, despite being a starfleet officer, might just hold true to every threat that they issued.
Captain Syrezeaju 10-Mar-21 09:50 PM
There was silence for the time between - a silence that ticked on. And on. And on. Eventually she spoke up - well aware that she could have followed their trail off of the conversation and into the fact that they had technically saved Nedras - not that they knew yet, it seemed - but this was her conversation and she was controlling it. Both her tone and posture remained casual, but those red eyes continued their glare. "You know something, Ensign? I find it quite surprising that these potentially classified documents weren't placed under lock in any way. Password, biometrics, the interior being encrypted. This is the Dominion that we're talking about after all. They're highly secretive - and their information doesn't fall into our hands easily. So I suppose what I'm trying to say..." She sat forwards again, gaze never wavering from the Ensign - but this time, her tone lowered. "...Is don't play games with me, Ensign."
12
12
10
Ensign Jaime Devereux 10-Mar-21 09:59 PM
Jaime took a short breath and sat fully upright. "I see, Captain... what is it you would like to know?" (edited)
Captain Syrezeaju 10-Mar-21 10:06 PM
The Rigellian continued to watch them closely. You could all but tell that she was analysing every movement, every audible inhale and exhale, every word that was stated. Their breath in - almost sharp - was noted. Something had gotten under their skin. She had posed something that they didn't like; and the reaction they gave was not one of the innocent and confused Ensign. It was one of someone who was well aware of what was happening here. "Who exactly are you, Ensign Devereux? You hold classified Dominion files which we both know an Ensign wouldn't be able to get their hands on even if family worked in that field. You're a fine Security officer, you do your job well, and you're obviously far more trained in showing respect than some officers your age. You like to send encrypted transmissions off to relays that are not our own - yes, I'm aware of that; why do you think that the communications officer is your roommate now? I know that your activity does not match that of a Starfleet officer. So, if you're not truly Starfleet, then who are you?" (edited)
10
Ensign Jaime Devereux 10-Mar-21 10:26 PM
"Captain Syrezeaju... The toxin within the implants of the Vorta is created via the use of morphogenic proteins... these proteins are not all that dissimilar from those which make up the founders themselves. This was discovered via the capture of Vorta during the Dominion War. As a means of preventing them from avoiding interrogation, there needed to be a way to nullify the effects of the toxin. This was not the only creation that the organization that I represent made to counteract morphogenic proteins..."
8
11
11
11
11
11
11
11
11
11
Captain Syrezeaju 10-Mar-21 10:32 PM
Her eyes narrowed once again, a pointed glare being shot directly at the Ensign. Her tone lowered alongside it, the grumbling, electronic tone almost sounding predatory. Of course she could jump to conclusions based on that response alone - but she wanted to hear it from them. "You did not answer my question, Ensign." (edited)
Ensign Jaime Devereux 10-Mar-21 10:35 PM
"I am Agent Jaime Taylor Devereux of Section Thirty-One." They said leaning forward in the chair.
15
13
13
13
12
Captain Syrezeaju 10-Mar-21 11:10 PM
Syre waited a moment while that information sunk in. Either time had frozen or she was impeccably still, and that stillness was only broken when she exhaled very slowly whilst lowering her head and putting both hands to the back of her neck as if it might somehow relieve the sudden tension there. "That's... Yeah. That's what I was worried about. I'm well aware that you'll have been told not to tell us anything in the event that you've been caught - but I'd like to think that you have at least an inkling of loyalty towards this ship and the crew that runs it." Keeping one hand in place at the back of her neck, she raised her head to look at him again. "What's your purpose aboard this ship, Agent?"
Ensign Jaime Devereux 10-Mar-21 11:22 PM
"My original purpose was to keep an eye on Phenna Ephrix in the weeks approaching her death. My secondary purpose was to report back threats to the Federation, such as the Nonbarafu from Gramen... have you heard much of them since?" Jaime asked, genuinely wondering whether or not any action had been taken by the Section. "After the Fleet Admiral's death, my secondary mission became my primary, with Command only sending infrequent updates, such as to capture Elija Noi. It was disappointing when he died. Section Thirty-One would have ensured he paid for his crimes; both against the Federation and against us. Section Thirty-One doesn't take treachery lightly." (edited)
Captain Syrezeaju 10-Mar-21 11:31 PM
"And neither does Starfleet," she stated back promptly, the anger seeming to flicker up from amidst that sudden weariness. "Elija Noi is dead and that is punishment enough - I don't like my officers stating that he should have suffered. We both know that the ideal of being humane is a Federation value and is not one only upheld by Starfleet. Your purpose was to 'report threats' despite that being precisely what Command and Intelligence themselves do on a daily basis. You have come aboard my ship, acted as a Starfleet officer - and seemed like a good officer for that time. You have continued to serve a group of people who are illegal within the Federation. I'm not going to ask you your motives, Ensign Devereux, but I'm going to ask you to seriously consider your next steps. Right now, the only ones I can see you taking will be the ones that guide you directly into the brig and then off into a jail cell."
Ensign Jaime Devereux 10-Mar-21 11:43 PM
"Despite my allegiance to Section Thirty-One, Captain... I have not acted as a Starfleet officer, I am a Starfleet officer. I went to the Academy, I achieved the grades I needed to graduate and join the fleet, I have only acted to aid the Federation, protect it and those I love from those that would do them harm by any means. Though... I would be the first to admit that the Section is flawed. Allowing Admiral Woy-whatever to influence the Command structure was a mistake. And, I won't tell you how many regulations I broke to get that cure to the medical team."
Captain Syrezeaju 11-Mar-21 12:12 AM
The glower she gave him turned into a downright snarl at the mention of Woystusyu's name - whether it was because of the mention of her in general or it was Jaime's failure to even try to say the name was yet to be determined. If the rare grin she gave from time to time could be described as sharp-toothed then this was even more so, an appearance which snapped back to the Jelna's more primitive and animalistic days. "Admiral Woystusyu did not influence the Command structure, she manipulated it from out of nowhere. She also used your organisation as her own personal agents - don't even think for a moment that we have forgotten how you carried out her bidding because you didn't know the truth about the Breen." Syrezeaju slinked back in her chair but the glare did not subside. "I don't care how many regulations you broke. I don't care how much trouble you're going to be in with them - you're going to be caught in quite the situation, in trouble with the two organisations that you work with. And if you are so worried about Section 31's regulation, Ensign, then why did you do it? Why help - and risk yourself getting caught?"
Ensign Jaime Devereux 11-Mar-21 12:26 AM
"When I referred to influencing the Command structure, I was referring to that of Section Thirty-One itself... though I must say I was not present for any of the incidents with the former Admiral, as I was stationed on the USS Challenger." They sat back again, and looked down towards their lap, before looking back up at the Captain again. "Does it surprise you that I have compassion? That I may have grown to care for members of this crew? If you believed that all of Section 31's agents were heartless bastards, I'm sorry to disappoint you." (edited)
Captain Syrezeaju 11-Mar-21 10:44 AM
"If you're so determined that you're still a Starfleet officer, Ensign, then you'll remember who you're speaking to and watch your language." The Rigellian's tone seemed to darken with every word and there was absolutely no denying just how infuriated this situation had made her. An attempted murder on one of her crew, a Section 31 officer having been hiding amongst their ranks for the duration of their time aboard... Despite their claims that Section 31 only wanted to defend the Federation, they were still a vile organisation. Devereux had been a threat to security all this time. How ironic, considering the colours they wore. "As for your question - no, it doesn't surprise me that you have compassion. It surprises me that you did such a thing while being so concerned about those regulations that you mention. It must have been dangerous for you, no? And surely you, a Section 31 officer and Starfleet officer as you say, would have been well aware of those risks. By procuring that information for us you led yourself into this situation. By procuring that information you went against Section 31's regulations. You're in trouble with us, Ensign, and undoubtedly you'll be in trouble with them." Her tone lightened but it was in an eerie way, almost mocking way. "I'd hate to know what Section 31 do to members who hand over their information to Starfleet."
Ensign Jaime Devereux 11-Mar-21 11:04 AM
"I apologise for my language, sir... I was... caught up in the moment." Jaime sat there with a look on their face that roughly translated to 'gods, kill me now'. They shook their head and then looked the Captain in the eyes, "As would I... but... Section 31 isn't what it used to be. Resources are sparse. What used to be a fleet of ships is now just a few runabouts. After Woystusyu, Section 31 was shut down. Those that were still loyal to the Agency and the Federation, rather than the Admiral, came together to form the new Section 31... round about its... 5th incarnation? And it hasn't been easy... Section 31 isn't what it used to be... they don't have the influence they used to, that's for sure..."
Captain Syrezeaju 11-Mar-21 11:39 AM
"You think that because they're lacking resources that they're not going to punish you?" Syre enquired, incredulous. "I know that you have this perception of them - one that you'll have been given by them - the one in which you're doing what you can to save the Federation? But beleive me, Ensign, that perception is wrong. You ain't even got their history right." Gaze never straying from them, she crossed her arms again. "Section 31 was shut down in 2441 - before your time, I know, but I'm sure that you'll have seen all of the reports that were leaked leading to their organisation being dissolved. We know that they've never simply been in defence of the Federation. They've always been vile; torturing prisoners of war for information, conducting genetic experiments on the people that they lured in? How many times did they break the conventions that the Federation swears upon - one that they would have to swear upon if they were truly working for the betterment of the Federation?" "I'm well aware that there were stragglers here and there. Little groups of four or five, trying to band together again and find their former power. Believe me, Ensign, I'm well aware - I've been chasing leads and hunting down those agents since before you were born. Hell, when Admiral Woystusyu decided to use you lot she didn't even use just you; she had to draft Intelligence into it because Section 31 barely had the manpower." "Look," she stated, sitting forwards a little again. "They may not have many resources but I can assure you that isn't going to stop them from punishing you. I've seen them eliminate people out in the field as soon as they were even close to being caught, and I've seen them tear cities apart trying to hunt down those who escaped their ranks. Kid, they're not going to just let you off with handing over their information to Starfleet - and, by extension, getting caught by 'em. They are going to end you." (edited)
Ensign Jaime Devereux 11-Mar-21 11:49 AM
"If that's the case... what have I got to lose, Captain?" Jaime sat back and looked off to the side. "Section 31 is not perfect. That is true. Yes, they have done terrible things and they will continue to do so... for what they think is right. Maybe... maybe they will come for me and if they do... well, we'll find out then won't we?" They sighed and looked down at the floor, "I didn't choose to join them... well... I did... but their recruitment process isn't exactly friendly to those who say no. Besides, I was born into this... my grandfather, and this much is true... he had been an Agent of the Section... that's why they came to me... the way Command sees it, the fewer people who know about them, the better... and how better to keep those numbers low than to recruit from the families of former agents?" (edited)
Captain Syrezeaju 11-Mar-21 01:02 PM
"I know of their tactics of recruiting people and making sure that they can't say no. Their recruitment methods and how they practically preyed upon people made up a large part of that inquest way back then. Look... Depending on what you want to do about all of this, that may well help to get you the sympathy vote from Command. Handing over information to save a fellow officer - at the cost of you getting caught - will also do the same." Syrezeaju tilted her head slightly, the glare of her red eyes softening a little as the anger dissipated. While Jaime may well have been a Section 31 agent and therefore a security threat aboard her ship, they were also an officer. They had proven themselves on missions and in reports. They were good at their job - and as much as she didn't like to let people off with things as severe as this, it would have been hypocritical if she didn't try to turn this around. "You need to think about your next steps. Section 31 are likely going to have your head for what you've done. Now - you're a good officer, albeit misled - some would say you're another victim of Section 31. Speaking with Command comes with risks, of course; they might just haul you off to jail themselves. But at the same time... This is a war. We don't want to lose officers. You have information that could help us - and maybe you chose to stay with Section 31, but your being hauled into their ranks may well have not been your fault. It isn't for me to decide, but - the option's there."
Ensign Jaime Devereux 11-Mar-21 01:24 PM
Jaime turned back to look at the Rigellian and sighed. "You're right. You are... and I- I can't stay now... even if I wanted to..." Jaime leaned back forward in their chair and rested their head in their hands. They weren't lying, they knew the Captain was right but... Section 31 are relentless, even if their resources are few and far between, there was something they had to ask. "Captain... if I turn myself in to Starfleet Command... can you swear that you will protect my mothers? You know what the Section is like... if they can't get me th-they'll..." They stopped speaking then altogether as the tears began to roll down their face. They couldn't finish that sentence because doing so might just make them realise how much danger their family was in... 'even Callum could be...' They turned away from the table in their chair and sank further into themself.
5
Captain Syrezeaju 11-Mar-21 02:33 PM
Whereas Jaime looked away, Syre's own gaze never seemed to falter - it only had done in that sole moment when they had stated that they were Section 31. With the anger having vanished it... Seemed very much like an 'I'm not angry, just disappointed' sort of situation. She gave the Ensign a moment, using that time to mentally plot out exactly what their next steps needed to be. Spirits, this was going to take quite the explanation when she called up Command. "What I'll do is get in touch with Command and inform them of the situation. I'll be certain to mention your family and they'll pass the information along to Security who should be able to arrange protection for them. If they can't, then there are a couple of people that I can speak to. Starfleet are understanding, though. They should be willing to help keep innocent people out of harm's way." "I'll get in touch with them as soon as I can. For now, effective immediately on stardate 155190.70, I am placing you under house arrest... As a precaution. You will be confined to your quarters - no visitors in. If anyone is vising a roommate that you have then you will be expected to stay within the confines of your own room. Your consoles will be locked out of all ship's systems and restricted access will be held. Any attempt to send an external communication will be monitored, and you will be sent to the brig if you attempt to send one. The same goes for doing anything untoward, such as leaving your quarters or trying to override your console's lock. You will also relinquish your commbadge and rank pips to me. Is that understood, Ensign Devereux?"
Ensign Jaime Devereux 11-Mar-21 02:41 PM
Jaime turned back around and nodded, "Yes sir... understood..." They then removed their badge and rank pip and slid them across the table to the Captain. "C-Can someone... t-tell Ensign Nedras... I-I'm worried about him... and... t-that I'm sorry...?"
8
Captain Syrezeaju 11-Mar-21 03:08 PM
"I'll pass the message along - although I would like to hope that he would be more thankful than anything, considering you've saved his life. Now go on, Ensign. And don't give me any reason to call a Security escort on you. I trust that you can be smart about all of this."
Ensign Jaime Devereux 11-Mar-21 03:10 PM
Jaime stood and nodded towards the Captain then left the Conference Room for the Turbolift.
Captain Syrezeaju 11-Mar-21 03:19 PM
Once Devereux had left she allowed herself a moment to decompress, leaning her head against the back of her chair and closing her eyes for a moment. Bloody Hell, why were officers like this? Why did this sort of thing always happen aboard her ship? First they were in the middle of a damned war, then there was an attempted murder, and now one of the security officers had turned out to be a goddamn Section 31 agent. What was worst of all was the fact that she may well have felt sorry for them. Damn, this was difficult. A minute ticked by and she forced herself back into functionality, turning towards her PADD which, as usual, had not stopped with the typical flurry of messages. Amidst them were Yllescas, Cas, and T'Svai's reports. At least one explained how Nedras had come to be almost assassinated - that was something else that she was going to have to talk to Command about. Yllescas' report was... God-awful, to say the least; not because of what he had written, but because of the basis of the information. What the Hell had Verne thought she was doing? This was just another goddamn stupid thing on top of everything else. At least T'Svai had kept her updated. Quickly she sent a message through to Operations, seeing as how the sooner they locked everything down for Devereux, the better.
To: @Operations Please enact full lock on quarters #al’khatib-devereux for Ensign Jaime Devereux. Al'Khatib should be allowed to leave quarters as required, but Devereux must remain within this area. Please lock his console and remove access to ship or external Starfleet systems; basic use only. Please ensure that communications cannot be sent from these quarters by Devreux, and if anything is sent, that it is monitored and reported immediately.
Once that was sent she then tapped her commbadge, this time to get in touch with her XO. "@Commander T'Svai from Syrezeaju. You wouldn't happen to still be free, would you?"
Commander T'Svai 11-Mar-21 03:22 PM
[Comms] "T'Svai here. I am."
Captain Syrezeaju 11-Mar-21 03:29 PM
"Is there any chance you could meet me down in the conference room? We need to talk over this report from Commander Yllescas and Ensign Cas Yardi - and there's another development that I need to make you aware of. It's related, but..." She huffed, not finding a good enough explanation. "You know what I mean."
Commander T'Svai 11-Mar-21 03:30 PM
[Comms] "I will meet you there shortly. T'Svai out."
T'Svai walked into the conference room and allowed the door to close behind her. She wasn't sure what to say for a moment, and eventually settled on words intended to express weary bewilderment (albeit conveyed in a neutral tone.) "There has been a development, Captain?"
Captain Syrezeaju 11-Mar-21 03:35 PM
Having sunk her head back against the chair again, it was only when T'Svai entered that she cracked one eye open to regard the Vulcan, not finding the sheer willpower to move from there for now. "You know Ensign Devereux - Security, the one mentioned in these reports of procuring that unidentified substance? Well: kid's nothing other than a Section 31 agent."
Commander T'Svai 11-Mar-21 03:37 PM
T'Svai was silent for several long seconds. "That is, in hindsight, unsurprising." She admitted, sitting down at the table. "I assume they have been placed under arrest?"
Captain Syrezeaju 11-Mar-21 03:39 PM
"They're confined to their quarters for now. I've just sent out the order to Operations to lock down their access to any fleet systems and ensure they can't send communications. It's... A bit of a tricky situation. It sounds as though they've been dragged into Section 31 due to familial relations - and it's not as if you can say no tho the group. I just wish the Ensign had said something sooner. Someone could have helped them instead of it having to come to this."
Commander T'Svai 11-Mar-21 03:59 PM
"It is possible that the encryption key they utilized in their communications was a cry for help. The destination for each message they sent was encrypted using the key thirty-one." T'Svai speculated. "As they gave up their cover to save the life of a colleague, I believe it is logical to speculate they are otherwise acting under duress. But that will be the decision of Command, in the end." She paused a moment and raised an eyebrow. "On the subject of duress, Captain, you do not appear well."
Captain Syrezeaju 11-Mar-21 04:03 PM
She barked out a laugh at that, clearly amused, but did make the effort to straighten up. "I'm alright, Commander, thank you - I just don't enjoy the news that one of my crew has been a spy this whole time and that another was almost murdered. By an ambassador, no less. It's going to take one heck of an explanation to Command."
Commander T'Svai 11-Mar-21 04:54 PM
"From what I understand, such things are common in the Gamma Quadrant. This is approximately equivalent to a Klingon ritual killing, albeit by an individual with diplomatic immunity." She mused, clearly having a little bit of trouble wrapping her head around it and trying to give it a cultural context to compensate. "Section 31 needs no context, and has often relied on such methods. I would imagine Command will be taken aback, but not altogether surprised." She speculated. "What course of action do you propose at this time, within the ship?"
Captain Syrezeaju 11-Mar-21 05:00 PM
"As I say, they've been confined to quarters and all of his equipment restricted for the time being. If they try to break out or establish contact outside of the ship, somehow, then they'll be headed straight for the brig. There's not much we can do until we speak with Command and see what they would like done. And then there's the issue with Lieutenant Verne."
Commander T'Svai 11-Mar-21 05:05 PM
T'Svai figured that was as good an answer as any. "While Lieutenant Verne and I can be considered acquaintances, rest assured that will have no impact on my judgement in this scenario. Her behavior was entirely unacceptable, and perhaps inevitable as well." She said very seriously. "I have been on more than one mission with the Lieutenant where she preemptively opened fire or pulled out a firearm, then expressed displeasure when reminded of protocol. However, I did not speculate that such behavior might be extended to her interactions with colleagues outside of such circumstances" She said, crossing her arms, a faint frown on her face. "Her words to the Commander in particular were entirely unacceptable."
Captain Syrezeaju 11-Mar-21 05:09 PM
"Verne was entirely out of line," Syre stated in response, nodding her head once in agreement. "Firstly by checking out a phaser no less - what was she going to do, threaten the man? Shoot them? She's Tactical, not Security - she shouldn't have taken matters into her own hands, and she more than certainly wasn't trained for the situation. I understand that she was upset because of what was happening within sickbay, but... She's the Assistant Chief Tactical Officer. She's aware of her place aboard this ship, she's aware of procedure and what's right and what isn't. She's also aware that she needs to show officers respect - something that she threw aside upon speaking with her CTO. Quite frankly, it's appalling. Aboard other ships, behaviour such as that would be counted as insubordination and she'd be finding herself in the brig." (edited)
Commander T'Svai 11-Mar-21 05:18 PM
"If you do not mind my asking, Captain, why not this one?" T'Svai asked, faintly perplexed. "We have no unique guidelines, and there has been an ACTO in training since I came aboard. If you fear any action you might take would substantially disrupt ship operations, in this particular scenario it appears unlikely." She explained. "Knowing that emotion drove her to violence does not remove the violence. In fact, it seems likely to precipitate more." (edited)
9
10
Captain Syrezeaju 11-Mar-21 05:35 PM
"I'm not the biggest fan of removing officers from duty, never mind putting them into the brig," she replied, scrubbing both hands over her face. "Verne made it up to Lieutenant and ACTO somehow - I'd like to think that she had proven herself in order to get there. ...Although, perhaps now she's proven otherwise and shown us that she really should not be holding those positions in the first place. You're quite right in that she's displayed violent tendencies. I'd like to hope that any form of punishment will drill it into her head that what she did wasn't right, but something definitely needs to be done, brig or otherwise. She's the assistant head of the division - not only is it dangerous, but she's setting one heck of a poor example for the junior members of the crew."
Commander T'Svai 11-Mar-21 05:46 PM
"I fail to see what else can be done." T'Svai commented, arching an eyebrow. "A natural first step, at minimum, would be a refresher course on proper protocol and suspending the Lieutenant's ability to remove firearms from the armory on her own authority. If she is upset now, she will grow more upset upon learning, as she will eventually, that the Ensign she visited is confined to quarters and an agent of Section 31." She suggested, leaning forward slightly. "Would any other Lieutenant on this ship have done such a thing? If not, I fail to see the relevance of rank."
Captain Syrezeaju 11-Mar-21 05:50 PM
"No, no, you're quite right... They wouldn't have. I don't like the concept of putting her in the brig, though. Hell, I didn't put the Section 31 agent in the brig - quarters will do for now. We'll pass this onto Command as well and see what they advise. It might be down to them speaking with her remotely and coming to that decision for us, for all we know." Another slow exhale, then. "...All of this because one ambassador decided to murder one of my crew. This isn't exactly the sort of thing that helps us win a war."
Commander T'Svai 11-Mar-21 05:52 PM
"I believe the Dominion would be more partial to the word 'terminate', but you are correct, Captain." T'Svai said grimly. "How is the Ensign? Is he deceased?"
Captain Syrezeaju 11-Mar-21 05:54 PM
"Oh, no, not at all - I should have said attempted to murder. Medical decided that the antidote that Ensign Devereux had was safe enough. They've administered it and apparently the Ensign is in stable condition, thankfully."
Commander T'Svai 11-Mar-21 05:56 PM
T'Svai's singular raised eyebrow strained to reach impossible new heights. "Fascinating." She said absently. "That will make the case against this Ambassador easier to support."
Captain Syrezeaju 11-Mar-21 05:58 PM
"I certainly hope so. I've heard bad things of her before, sooner or later the Diplomatic Corps will have to do something about it. ...And now we have to face the dreaded next steps, don't we?" Syre stated, although did not clarify those 'dreaded next steps' until a moment later. "Spirits, I hate talking with Command..."
Commander T'Svai 11-Mar-21 06:00 PM
T'Svai contemplated volunteering, but decided against it. "Should you wish to delegate some of your other duties to prepare, I can assist." She offered instead.
Captain Syrezeaju 11-Mar-21 06:02 PM
"If you want to do the written report for me then please, by all means, go ahead." Both hands placed down upon the table, she hauled herself to her feet again - and then glanced sideways to T'Svai with a very slight smile. "I'm joking, of course. Don't worry about it. We'll get it all done."
Commander T'Svai 11-Mar-21 06:04 PM
T'Svai hummed in acknowledgment at the joke. "Indeed." She tilted her head minutely to one side. "I have been meaning to ask - I expressed a wish to the previous First Officer to compile a report on your... experience that led to you being temporarily incapacitated," she understated, " and have since been informed that the Admiralty has compiled their own report, which I was not privy to. Is there anything I or any of the other Senior Staff should know?"
Captain Syrezeaju 11-Mar-21 06:09 PM
Having been about to make a move to leave the room and head on back up to the bridge, Syre ended up halting with one hand upon the back of the chair she had previously occupied. Of course someone was going to ask eventually. The admiralty's own enquiry into it all had been before the war had been announced and before the masses knew that the Iconians were behind it all. It was strange how long ago yet how recent the occurrence simultaneously felt. There was a brief moment before she turned back to T'Svai, perhaps the slightest bit hesitant... But also being well aware that she had the right to know, especially as the ship's XO. "Well... It solely depends on what you want to know. I'm sorry that you haven't been informed of anything beforehand; the admiralty wanted everything kept hush-hush because it was before they were ready to announce that it was the Iconians behind it all. They were still trying to keep up with everythingm as far as I'm aware."
Commander T'Svai 11-Mar-21 06:12 PM
"Seeing as I presently know nothing, it is not possible to substantially narrow the field of questions I wish to ask." T'Svai replied dryly. "The Iconians did... something that resulted in grievous harm to your person, and it is unclear if there was an intent behind it other than mere cruelty. If you perceive another motive, that may be useful to know. I understand if you do not wish to discuss it."
Captain Syrezeaju 11-Mar-21 06:27 PM
"They wanted information," she started, slinging her other arm up onto the back of the chair as well. Her tone was steady, but the electronic grumble to those bio-engineered vocal cords only served as a reminder of what had occurred. "They wanted different information from all of us. For some it was ship schematics, for others it was information on the Federations' defences. For me -" she paused and actually laughed, shaking her head for a moment. When she spoke again, her gaze had found its way to the tabletop, no longer meeting T'Svai's own. "For me, they asked what I knew of them. If only they had left it a couple of days before snatching me up on the way back... I would have been to that meeting then. I actually would have known."
Commander T'Svai 11-Mar-21 06:38 PM
T'Svai took a few moments to let that sink in, because it was logical, but in an awful, cruel way that made her glad Vulcan logic valued morality. "It is highly fortunate, then, that their timing was so poor." She said absently. "I am sorry you had to experience such a thing, and that I prompted you to recall it." To add insult to injury, there seemed to be nothing immediately actionable there. "With that I have no further questions, Captain."
Captain Syrezeaju 11-Mar-21 07:02 PM
"There's no need to apologise, Commander, don't worry. It happened - and that's all there is to it." What she didn't comment on was the fact that T'Svai viewed their timing as fortunate. If their timing had been a bit better and Syre had been able to tell them anything, then... Starfleet officers were supposed to be trained to withstand torture. She had been trained by Security, and the SCIS, and FedSec all individually. So why was it that now, all of that training had fallen through? ...When it was the real deal things were far different, it seemed. "I'll go and see about getting in touch with Command about all of this." She pushed herself back from the chair again and began to head to the door. "Wish me luck."
Commander T'Svai 11-Mar-21 07:05 PM
"Vulcans do not believe in luck." T'Svai replied as a parting greeting, eyebrow finally lowering. "Peace and long life." She decided to catch up on her other, less chaotic reports. (edited)
Exported 2,506 message(s)
